metadata.solver_version: Enhanced AI Solver v2.0 with Quality Control

questions.question_text: A student uses a metre ruler to measure the length of six identical table-tennis balls placed between two wooden blocks. What is the diameter of one ball?
questions.explanation: The six balls span from 38 cm to 62 cm on the ruler, giving a total length of 24 cm. Since the balls are identical, the diameter of one ball = 24 cm ÷ 6 = 4 cm.
formula_used: diameter = total length ÷ number of objects
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Measurement and experimental techniques

questions.question_text: A train is on a straight track. The graph shows how a quantity y varies with time. Which statements can be true? 1 The train is stationary and y represents the distance from the last station. 2 The train is moving and y represents the distance from the last station. 3 The train is stationary and y represents the speed of the train. 4 The train is moving and y represents the speed of the train.
questions.explanation: The graph shows y as a constant positive value over time. Statement 1 is true: if the train is stationary at a fixed distance from a station, this distance remains constant. Statement 4 is true: if the train moves at constant speed, the speed-time graph would be horizontal. Statement 2 is false: if the train were moving, distance from a station would change. Statement 3 is false: a stationary train has zero speed, but the graph shows a positive constant value.
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Motion graphs and interpretation

questions.question_text: A vehicle sent to explore the surface of Mars has a mass of 200 kg. The acceleration of free fall on Mars is 3.7 m/s². What is the weight of the vehicle on Mars?
questions.explanation: Weight is calculated using W = mg. Given: mass = 200 kg, gravitational acceleration on Mars = 3.7 m/s². Weight = 200 kg × 3.7 m/s² = 740 N.
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Weight and gravitational force

questions.question_text: A student writes about mass and weight. Which statement is correct?

options.A: A ship which is floating has mass but no weight.
options.B: Mass is a scientific word that means the same as weight.
options.D: The mass of an astronaut is the same on the Moon as on the Earth.

questions.explanation: Mass is an intrinsic property of matter that does not change with location or gravitational field. An astronaut's mass remains constant whether on Earth, Moon, or anywhere else. Option A is incorrect because floating objects still have weight (buoyant force balances weight). Option B is incorrect because mass and weight are different quantities. Option C is incorrect because mass is measured in kilograms, while weight (force) is measured in newtons.
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Mass and weight distinction

questions.question_text: A student carries out an experiment to determine the density of an irregularly shaped solid. The solid is placed on a balance and a reading is taken. The solid is then immersed in a liquid in a measuring cylinder. Which values should be used in the calculation?

options.A: increase in reading after immersion of the solid / mass
options.B: increase in reading after immersion of the solid / weight
options.C: reading after immersion of the solid / mass
options.D: reading after immersion of the solid / weight

questions.explanation: Density = mass / volume. The mass is obtained from the balance reading. The volume of an irregularly shaped solid is found by measuring the increase in liquid level when the solid is immersed (displacement method). The increase in reading gives the volume of the solid. Therefore, density = mass / increase in reading after immersion.
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Density measurement and displacement method

questions.question_text: A uniform rod rests on a pivot at its centre. The rod is not attached to the pivot. Forces are then applied to the rod in four different ways, as shown. The weight of the rod can be ignored. Which diagram shows the rod in equilibrium?

options.A: 100N downward on left end, 100N downward on right end
options.B: 100N upward from left end, 100N upward from right end
options.C: 100N upward on left end, 100N downward on right end
options.D: 100N upward on left end, 100N downward on left side, 100N downward on right end

questions.explanation: For equilibrium, the net force must be zero and the net moment about the pivot must be zero. In option C: Net force = 100N up - 100N down = 0. Net moment = (100N × distance) clockwise - (100N × distance) anticlockwise = 0. The rod is balanced with equal and opposite forces at equal distances from the pivot.
formula_used: sum of clockwise moments = sum of anticlockwise moments
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Moments and equilibrium

questions.question_text: The diagram shows a beam balanced on a pivot. Two forces, X and Y, are acting on the beam. Which calculation gives the moment of the force Y about the pivot?
questions.explanation: The moment of a force about a pivot is calculated using: moment = force × perpendicular distance from the pivot. Force Y is at a perpendicular distance b from the pivot, so the moment of force Y about the pivot = Y × b.
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Moments and turning effects

questions.question_text: A mass bounces up and down on a steel spring. The diagram shows the mass and the spring at different points during the motion. At which point is the least energy in the gravitational potential store of the mass and at which point is the most energy in the elastic store of the spring?

options.A: mass moving down / mass moving up

questions.explanation: Gravitational potential energy is least when the mass is at its lowest position (lowest point). Elastic potential energy in the spring is greatest when the spring is most compressed or stretched, which occurs at the lowest point where maximum compression happens. At this point, all the energy is stored as elastic potential energy in the compressed spring.
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Energy transfers and stores

questions.question_text: Electrical power is generated from different resources. Some of these resources are listed. • chemical energy stored in biofuels • chemical energy stored in fossil fuels • energy stored in tides • geothermal resources • hydroelectric resources • light from the Sun • nuclear fuel How many of the resources listed are classified as renewable?
questions.explanation: Renewable resources are those that can be replenished naturally within a human timescale. From the list: Renewable: biofuels (✓), tides (✓), geothermal (✓), hydroelectric (✓), solar/Sun (✓) = 5 resources. Non-renewable: fossil fuels (✗), nuclear fuel (✗) = 2 resources. Therefore, 5 resources are renewable.
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Energy resources and sustainability

questions.question_text: A microwave oven is rated at 900 watts. Which statement correctly describes the meaning of this value?
questions.explanation: Power is defined as the rate of energy transfer, measured in watts (W). One watt equals one joule per second (1 W = 1 J/s). Therefore, a 900-watt microwave oven transfers 900 joules of energy every second. Options B, C, and D are incorrect because amperes, volts, and ohms are not measures of energy transfer rate.
questions.detailed_topic: Power and energy in electrical circuits
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Power and energy in electrical circuits

questions.question_text: Why is it easier to push a sharp nail, rather than a blunt nail, into a piece of wood?

options.A: The sharp nail exerts a larger force on the wood.
options.B: The sharp nail exerts a smaller force on the wood.
options.C: The sharp nail exerts a larger pressure on the wood.
options.D: The sharp nail exerts a smaller pressure on the wood.

questions.explanation: Pressure is defined as force per unit area (P = F/A). A sharp nail has a much smaller contact area at its point compared to a blunt nail. When the same force is applied, the sharp nail creates a much larger pressure because the force is concentrated over a smaller area. This higher pressure allows the nail to penetrate the wood more easily.
questions.subject: physics
questions.learning_objective: Understand and apply Pressure and force
